Situation1: They notice a mentee struggling with time management during casual check-ins.
Situation2: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Story:
I glanced at the clock above the register, mentally counting down the minutes until my break. As a cashier, I kept my smile ready, greeting the next customer with a practiced warmth while scanning their groceries. Out of the corner of my eye, I noticed Jamie, my mentee from the store’s training program, hovering near the end of the aisle. She looked frazzled, clutching her notepad, her eyes darting between the clock and her unfinished restocking cart. I remembered our last check-in, when she admitted she was struggling to balance her tasks and felt overwhelmed by the pace.

I wanted to step away, to offer her a few words of encouragement, maybe share a tip or two about managing time on the floor. But the line at my register was growing, and I could feel the customers’ impatience simmering. My manager expected me to keep things moving and maintain a cheerful demeanor. I felt torn—my role as a mentor urging me to support Jamie, my duty as a cashier demanding I stay focused on the customers. My heart raced as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure which role to honor in that moment.
